questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to OPD with complaint of itching in vagina, discharge from vagina and dyspareunia. Best treatment option would be:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In postmenopausal women, symptoms like vaginal itching, discharge, and dyspareunia are often due to decreased estrogen levels, leading to atrophic vaginitis. Vaginal estrogen therapy is an effective treatment for atrophic vaginitis, addressing the underlying hormonal deficiency.
  • ➤ Ref: Berek & Novak, 16 ed Page 891
  • ➤ Ref: Berek & Novak, 16 ed Page 891

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with multiple sexual partners comes with complaint of vaginal discharge. On examination, cervix is eroded with mucopurulent discharge. Which of the following kits will you give her:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kit 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In syndromic approach Kit 1: gray: urethral discharge (men), cervical discharge (women) Kit 2: green: vaginal discharge Kit 6: yellow kit: PID/ lower abdominal pain syndrome Kit 3: white / 4 blue: non herpetic ulcers Kit 5: red: herpetic ulcer Kit 7: black: inguinal bubo
  • ➤ In syndromic approach Kit 1: gray: urethral discharge (men), cervical discharge (women) Kit 2: green: vaginal discharge Kit 6: yellow kit: PID/ lower abdominal pain syndrome Kit 3: white / 4 blue: non herpetic ulcers Kit 5: red: herpetic ulcer Kit 7: black: inguinal bubo
  • ➤ In syndromic approach
  • ➤ Kit 1: gray: urethral discharge (men), cervical discharge (women) Kit 2: green: vaginal discharge Kit 6: yellow kit: PID/ lower abdominal pain syndrome Kit 3: white / 4 blue: non herpetic ulcers Kit 5: red: herpetic ulcer Kit 7: black: inguinal bubo
  • ➤ Kit 1: gray: urethral discharge (men), cervical discharge (women)
  • ➤ Kit 2: green: vaginal discharge
  • ➤ Kit 6: yellow kit: PID/ lower abdominal pain syndrome
  • ➤ Kit 3: white / 4 blue: non herpetic ulcers
  • ➤ Kit 5: red: herpetic ulcer
  • ➤ Kit 7: black: inguinal bubo

questions.text: A woman with multiple sexual partners, presents with recurrent genital ulcers. Probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Herpes genitalis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes genitalis is known for its recurrent nature, they typically start as blisters that become painful ulcers making it a likely cause in a patient with recurrent genital ulcers. In contrast, genital warts (HPV), syphilis, and chancroid present differently.
  • ➤ Ref: Berek & Novak 16 ed, page 899

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding female genital tuberculosis (FGTB)?

options.label: A
options.text: FGTB is usually secondary to pulmonary TB through hematogenous route or lymphatic route

options.label: B
options.text: Rarely, infection can occur through infected semen from tuberculous orchitis in males

options.label: C
options.text: The most common organism is Mycobacterium bovis due to consumption of unpasteurized milk in villages

options.label: D
options.text: Cervical TB may mimic cervical cancer causing abnormal vaginal discharge or cervical ulcers and growths

questions.correct_answer: C. The most common organism is Mycobacterium bovis due to consumption of unpasteurized milk in villages
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. The most common organism is Mycobacterium bovis due to consumption of unpasteurized milk in villages

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Let’s discuss all options:
  • • Let’s discuss all options:
  • • Option A: FGTB is usually secondary to pulmonary TB through hematogenous route or lymphatic route: This is a correct statement. FGTB is usually secondary to pulmonary TB through hematogenous route or lymphatic route but can occur through contagious spread from adjacent ileocecal TB and rarely through infected semen from tuberculous orchitis in males Option B: Rarely, infection can occur through infected semen from tuberculous orchitis in males. This is also a correct statement. FGTB is usually secondary to pulmonary TB through hematogenous route or lymphatic route but can occur through contagious spread from adjacent ileocecal TB and rarely through infected semen from tuberculous orchitis in males Option C: The most common organism is Mycobacterium bovis due to consumption of unpasteurized milk in villages. This is an INCORRECT statement, Although M. bovis infection can occur due to consumption of unpasteurized milk, the most common organism is Mycobacterium tuberculous. Option D: Cervical TB may mimic cervical cancer causing abnormal vaginal discharge or cervical ulcers and growth. This is also a correct statement. Among the various sites, fallopian tubes are mostly affected (90–100%) followed by uterus (70%), ovaries (30%), cervix (10%) and rarely vulva and vagina (1% each). Abdomino-pelvic TB may cause peritoneal adhesions, nodules and ascites and may simulate ovarian cancer. Similarly, cervical TB may mimic cervical cancer causing abnormal vaginal discharge or cervical, vulval and vaginal ulcers.
  • • Option A: FGTB is usually secondary to pulmonary TB through hematogenous route or lymphatic route: This is a correct statement. FGTB is usually secondary to pulmonary TB through hematogenous route or lymphatic route but can occur through contagious spread from adjacent ileocecal TB and rarely through infected semen from tuberculous orchitis in males
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Rarely, infection can occur through infected semen from tuberculous orchitis in males. This is also a correct statement. FGTB is usually secondary to pulmonary TB through hematogenous route or lymphatic route but can occur through contagious spread from adjacent ileocecal TB and rarely through infected semen from tuberculous orchitis in males
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: The most common organism is Mycobacterium bovis due to consumption of unpasteurized milk in villages. This is an INCORRECT statement, Although M. bovis infection can occur due to consumption of unpasteurized milk, the most common organism is Mycobacterium tuberculous.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Cervical TB may mimic cervical cancer causing abnormal vaginal discharge or cervical ulcers and growth. This is also a correct statement. Among the various sites, fallopian tubes are mostly affected (90–100%) followed by uterus (70%), ovaries (30%), cervix (10%) and rarely vulva and vagina (1% each). Abdomino-pelvic TB may cause peritoneal adhesions, nodules and ascites and may simulate ovarian cancer. Similarly, cervical TB may mimic cervical cancer causing abnormal vaginal discharge or cervical, vulval and vaginal ulcers.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FGTB is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis but can also be rarely caused by Mycobacterium bovis due to consumption of unpasteurized milk in villages. Genital infection is usually secondary to pulmonary TB or intestinal TB through hematogenous or lymphatic route and is more common in immunocompromised people or with chronic medical diseases including HIV and COVID-19 Among the various sites, fallopian tubes are mostly affected (90–100%) followed by uterus (70%), ovaries (30%), cervix (10%) and rarely vulva and vagina (1% each). Abdomino-pelvic TB may cause peritoneal adhesions, nodules and ascites and may simulate ovarian cancer [30]. Similarly, cervical TB may mimic cervical cancer causing abnormal vaginal discharge or cervical, vulval and vaginal ulcers.
  • ➤ FGTB is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis but can also be rarely caused by Mycobacterium bovis due to consumption of unpasteurized milk in villages.
  • ➤ Genital infection is usually secondary to pulmonary TB or intestinal TB through hematogenous or lymphatic route and is more common in immunocompromised people or with chronic medical diseases including HIV and COVID-19
  • ➤ Among the various sites, fallopian tubes are mostly affected (90–100%) followed by uterus (70%), ovaries (30%), cervix (10%) and rarely vulva and vagina (1% each). Abdomino-pelvic TB may cause peritoneal adhesions, nodules and ascites and may simulate ovarian cancer [30]. Similarly, cervical TB may mimic cervical cancer causing abnormal vaginal discharge or cervical, vulval and vaginal ulcers.
  • ➤ Ref: Sharma JB, Sharma E, Sharma S, Dharmendra S. Female genital tuberculosis: Revisited. Indian J Med Res. 2018 Dec;148(Suppl):S71-S83. doi: 10.4103/ijmr.IJMR_648_18. PMID: 30964083; PMCID: PMC6469382.
  • ➤ Ref: Sharma JB, Sharma E, Sharma S, Dharmendra S. Female genital tuberculosis: Revisited.
  • ➤ Indian J Med Res. 2018 Dec;148(Suppl):S71-S83. doi: 10.4103/ijmr.IJMR_648_18. PMID: 30964083; PMCID: PMC6469382.

questions.text: A 20y old girl presents with low grade fever and a few months of amenorrhoea. Prior to this she had scanty flow for a few months. On examination, her BMI is 16. Abdominal exam reveals ascites. There is no mass palpable. An ultrasound reveals a right sided adnexal lesion with ascites. What is the best diagnostic tool for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Laparoscopy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The suspected diagnosis in this patient is genital TB as she has a h/o fever and amenorrhoea, there is weight loss, ascites and the ultrasound shows an adnexal mass. The diagnosis of genital TB is complex and involves microbiological tests, imaging and endoscopy. As it is a paucibacillary infection, microbiology may not be positive although if there is a suspicion, an endometrial biopsy for microbiology and HPE is usually always done Laparoscopy is the best diagnostic tool to detect FGTB by direct visualization of TB lesions on tubes like tubercles and caseous nodules and to take biopsy
  • • The suspected diagnosis in this patient is genital TB as she has a h/o fever and amenorrhoea, there is weight loss, ascites and the ultrasound shows an adnexal mass.
  • • The diagnosis of genital TB is complex and involves microbiological tests, imaging and endoscopy.
  • • As it is a paucibacillary infection, microbiology may not be positive although if there is a suspicion, an endometrial biopsy for microbiology and HPE is usually always done
  • • Laparoscopy is the best diagnostic tool to detect FGTB by direct visualization of TB lesions on tubes like tubercles and caseous nodules and to take biopsy
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A: HSG: This is not usually done for diagnosing genital TB but signs in HSG are picked up if it was done for tubal factor infertility. It is in fact avoided in acute disease to avoid fare-up. Various findings of FGTB can be blocked tubes, (usually cornual block) tobacco-pouch appearance of tubes, beaded tubes, filling defects in uterine cavity. (Asherman’s syndrome) Option B: 3D USG: This is not very beneficial in suspected genital TB but very useful in Mullerian anomalies Option C: MRI: Computerized tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and positron emission tomography (PET): any one of the three modalities can be used for tuberculous tubo-ovarian masses. MRI has higher resolution especially for TB lymphadenitis. PET-CT can demonstrate increased FDG uptake of tuberculous tubo-ovarian masses. But tese are not the best diagnostic tools.
  • • Option A: HSG: This is not usually done for diagnosing genital TB but signs in HSG are picked up if it was done for tubal factor infertility. It is in fact avoided in acute disease to avoid fare-up. Various findings of FGTB can be blocked tubes, (usually cornual block) tobacco-pouch appearance of tubes, beaded tubes, filling defects in uterine cavity. (Asherman’s syndrome)
  • • Option A: HSG:
  • • Option B: 3D USG: This is not very beneficial in suspected genital TB but very useful in Mullerian anomalies
  • • Option B: 3D USG:
  • • Option C: MRI: Computerized tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and positron emission tomography (PET): any one of the three modalities can be used for tuberculous tubo-ovarian masses. MRI has higher resolution especially for TB lymphadenitis. PET-CT can demonstrate increased FDG uptake of tuberculous tubo-ovarian masses. But tese are not the best diagnostic tools.
  • • Option C: MRI:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Investigations in Genital TB:
  • ➤ Investigations in Genital TB:
  • ➤ Ref: Sharma JB, Sharma E, Sharma S, Dharmendra S. Female genital tuberculosis: Revisited. Indian J Med Res. 2018 Dec;148(Suppl):S71-S83. doi: 10.4103/ijmr.IJMR_648_18. PMID: 30964083; PMCID: PMC6469382.
  • ➤ Ref: Sharma JB, Sharma E, Sharma S, Dharmendra S. Female genital tuberculosis: Revisited.
  • ➤ Indian J Med Res. 2018 Dec;148(Suppl):S71-S83. doi: 10.4103/ijmr.IJMR_648_18. PMID: 30964083; PMCID: PMC6469382.

questions.text: A diagnostic laparoscopy was done for a 34y woman with unexplained infertility. The following was seen on laparoscopy where the fallopian tubes appeared to be adherent to each other. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Genital TB

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is the kissing fallopian tube sign which is typically seen on laparoscopy in genital TB. Laparoscopy findings in female genital TB are: Perihepatic adhesions and Sharma’s hanging gall bladder sign Sharma’s ascending colonic adhesion Sharma’s sigmoid colonic adhesive band Sharma’s parachute sign (adhesions of ascending colon to abdominal wall) Sharma’s compartmentalization sign (multiple compartments are formed by omental adhesions to contain infection) Fallopian tubes distended with alternate constrictions and dilatations on laparoscopy and dye test resembling blue python in FGTB cases (Sharma’s blue python sign) Fusion of both fallopian tubes due to FGTB (Sharma’s kissing fallopian tubes sign)
  • • This is the kissing fallopian tube sign which is typically seen on laparoscopy in genital TB. Laparoscopy findings in female genital TB are: Perihepatic adhesions and Sharma’s hanging gall bladder sign Sharma’s ascending colonic adhesion Sharma’s sigmoid colonic adhesive band Sharma’s parachute sign (adhesions of ascending colon to abdominal wall) Sharma’s compartmentalization sign (multiple compartments are formed by omental adhesions to contain infection) Fallopian tubes distended with alternate constrictions and dilatations on laparoscopy and dye test resembling blue python in FGTB cases (Sharma’s blue python sign) Fusion of both fallopian tubes due to FGTB (Sharma’s kissing fallopian tubes sign)
  • • Perihepatic adhesions and Sharma’s hanging gall bladder sign Sharma’s ascending colonic adhesion Sharma’s sigmoid colonic adhesive band Sharma’s parachute sign (adhesions of ascending colon to abdominal wall) Sharma’s compartmentalization sign (multiple compartments are formed by omental adhesions to contain infection) Fallopian tubes distended with alternate constrictions and dilatations on laparoscopy and dye test resembling blue python in FGTB cases (Sharma’s blue python sign) Fusion of both fallopian tubes due to FGTB (Sharma’s kissing fallopian tubes sign)
  • • Perihepatic adhesions and Sharma’s hanging gall bladder sign
  • • Sharma’s ascending colonic adhesion
  • • Sharma’s sigmoid colonic adhesive band
  • • Sharma’s parachute sign (adhesions of ascending colon to abdominal wall)
  • • Sharma’s compartmentalization sign (multiple compartments are formed by omental adhesions to contain infection)
  • • Fallopian tubes distended with alternate constrictions and dilatations on laparoscopy and dye test resembling blue python in FGTB cases (Sharma’s blue python sign)
  • • Fusion of both fallopian tubes due to FGTB (Sharma’s kissing fallopian tubes sign)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Endometriosis: Laparoscopy findings of laparoscopy include Endometriotic lesions (blue, black, red and white lesions on different areas – commonly on the ovary, fallopian tubes, peritoneum, uterine serosa, POD, round ligaments etc) Ovarian endometrioma (Chocolate cyst) Adhesions (tubal/ peritoneal) Nodules/ adhesions/ obliteration of the Pouch of Douglas Option C: Chlamydial PID: Peri hepatic adhesions (Fits Hugh Curtis syndrome) Inflamed and congested uterus and adnexa Pelvic abscesses and tubo ovarian masses Option D: Fimbrial block: When Chromotubation is done and there is fimbrial block, dye will collect in the tube and dilate it (hydrosalpinx)
  • • Option A: Endometriosis: Laparoscopy findings of laparoscopy include Endometriotic lesions (blue, black, red and white lesions on different areas – commonly on the ovary, fallopian tubes, peritoneum, uterine serosa, POD, round ligaments etc) Ovarian endometrioma (Chocolate cyst) Adhesions (tubal/ peritoneal) Nodules/ adhesions/ obliteration of the Pouch of Douglas
  • • Option A: Endometriosis:
  • • Endometriotic lesions (blue, black, red and white lesions on different areas – commonly on the ovary, fallopian tubes, peritoneum, uterine serosa, POD, round ligaments etc) Ovarian endometrioma (Chocolate cyst) Adhesions (tubal/ peritoneal) Nodules/ adhesions/ obliteration of the Pouch of Douglas
  • • Endometriotic lesions (blue, black, red and white lesions on different areas – commonly on the ovary, fallopian tubes, peritoneum, uterine serosa, POD, round ligaments etc)
  • • Ovarian endometrioma (Chocolate cyst)
  • • Adhesions (tubal/ peritoneal)
  • • Nodules/ adhesions/ obliteration of the Pouch of Douglas
  • • Option C: Chlamydial PID: Peri hepatic adhesions (Fits Hugh Curtis syndrome) Inflamed and congested uterus and adnexa Pelvic abscesses and tubo ovarian masses
  • • Option C: Chlamydial PID:
  • • Peri hepatic adhesions (Fits Hugh Curtis syndrome) Inflamed and congested uterus and adnexa Pelvic abscesses and tubo ovarian masses
  • • Peri hepatic adhesions (Fits Hugh Curtis syndrome)
  • • Inflamed and congested uterus and adnexa
  • • Pelvic abscesses and tubo ovarian masses
  • • Option D: Fimbrial block: When Chromotubation is done and there is fimbrial block, dye will collect in the tube and dilate it (hydrosalpinx)
  • • Option D: Fimbrial block:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Findings on laparoscopy in female genital TB are: Perihepatic adhesions and Sharma’s hanging gall bladder sign Sharma’s ascending colonic adhesion Sharma’s sigmoid colonic adhesive band Sharma’s parachute sign (adhesions of ascending colon to abdominal wall) Sharma’s compartmentalization sign (multiple compartments are formed by omental adhesions to contain infection) Fallopian tubes distended with alternate constrictions and dilatations on laparoscopy and dye test resembling blue python in FGTB cases (Sharma’s blue python sign) Fusion of both fallopian tubes due to FGTB (Sharma’s kissing fallopian tubes sign)
  • ➤ Findings on laparoscopy in female genital TB are: Perihepatic adhesions and Sharma’s hanging gall bladder sign Sharma’s ascending colonic adhesion Sharma’s sigmoid colonic adhesive band Sharma’s parachute sign (adhesions of ascending colon to abdominal wall) Sharma’s compartmentalization sign (multiple compartments are formed by omental adhesions to contain infection) Fallopian tubes distended with alternate constrictions and dilatations on laparoscopy and dye test resembling blue python in FGTB cases (Sharma’s blue python sign) Fusion of both fallopian tubes due to FGTB (Sharma’s kissing fallopian tubes sign)
  • ➤ Perihepatic adhesions and Sharma’s hanging gall bladder sign Sharma’s ascending colonic adhesion Sharma’s sigmoid colonic adhesive band Sharma’s parachute sign (adhesions of ascending colon to abdominal wall) Sharma’s compartmentalization sign (multiple compartments are formed by omental adhesions to contain infection) Fallopian tubes distended with alternate constrictions and dilatations on laparoscopy and dye test resembling blue python in FGTB cases (Sharma’s blue python sign) Fusion of both fallopian tubes due to FGTB (Sharma’s kissing fallopian tubes sign)
  • ➤ Perihepatic adhesions and Sharma’s hanging gall bladder sign
  • ➤ Sharma’s ascending colonic adhesion
  • ➤ Sharma’s sigmoid colonic adhesive band
  • ➤ Sharma’s parachute sign (adhesions of ascending colon to abdominal wall)
  • ➤ Sharma’s compartmentalization sign (multiple compartments are formed by omental adhesions to contain infection)
  • ➤ Fallopian tubes distended with alternate constrictions and dilatations on laparoscopy and dye test resembling blue python in FGTB cases (Sharma’s blue python sign)
  • ➤ Fusion of both fallopian tubes due to FGTB (Sharma’s kissing fallopian tubes sign)
  • ➤ Ref: Sharma JB, Sharma E, Sharma S, Dharmendra S. Female genital tuberculosis: Revisited. Indian J Med Res. 2018 Dec;148(Suppl):S71-S83. doi: 10.4103/ijmr.IJMR_648_18. PMID: 30964083; PMCID: PMC6469382.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a tubal sign of genital TB seen on HSG?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Asherman syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Asherman syndrome is intrauterine adhesions and is seen as multiple filling defects on the HSG. It is not a tubal sign. All the others (golf club, lead pipe, tobacco pouch) are HSG signs
  • • Asherman syndrome is intrauterine adhesions and is seen as multiple filling defects on the HSG. It is not a tubal sign.
  • • All the others (golf club, lead pipe, tobacco pouch) are HSG signs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HSG findings of genital TB
  • ➤ HSG findings of genital TB
  • ➤ Tubal Strictures Beading Golf club sign Tobacco pouch sign Lead pipe appearance Cornual block (more common than fimbrial) Fimbrial block Hydrosalpinx Uterine: Intra uterine filling defects due to adhesions: Asherman syndrome
  • ➤ Tubal Strictures Beading Golf club sign Tobacco pouch sign Lead pipe appearance Cornual block (more common than fimbrial) Fimbrial block Hydrosalpinx
  • ➤ Strictures Beading Golf club sign Tobacco pouch sign Lead pipe appearance Cornual block (more common than fimbrial) Fimbrial block Hydrosalpinx
  • ➤ Strictures
  • ➤ Beading
  • ➤ Golf club sign
  • ➤ Tobacco pouch sign
  • ➤ Lead pipe appearance
  • ➤ Cornual block (more common than fimbrial)
  • ➤ Fimbrial block
  • ➤ Hydrosalpinx
  • ➤ Uterine: Intra uterine filling defects due to adhesions: Asherman syndrome

questions.text: A 25y old infertile woman is started on anti-tubercular treatment in view of genital TB diagnosed on peritoneal biopsy on laparoscopy done for tubal factor infertility. What is the regime she should receive?

options.label: A
options.text: 2 months initiation phase with rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol followed by 4 months continuation phase with rifampicin and isoniazid

options.label: B
options.text: 2 months initiation phase with rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol followed by 4 months continuation phase with rifampicin, isoniazid and ethambutol

options.label: C
options.text: 2 months initiation phase with rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol followed by 10 months continuation phase with rifampicin and isoniazid

options.label: D
options.text: 2 months initiation phase with rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol followed by 10 months continuation phase with rifampicin, isoniazid and ethambutol

questions.correct_answer: B. 2 months initiation phase with rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol followed by 4 months continuation phase with rifampicin, isoniazid and ethambutol
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 2 months initiation phase with rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol followed by 4 months continuation phase with rifampicin, isoniazid and ethambutol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Treatment of Female Genital TB consists of
  • • Treatment of Female Genital TB consists of
  • • The intensive phase (4 drugs) four drugs regimen for 2 months with daily oral: Rifampicin (r) Isoniazid (h) Pyrazinamide (z) Ethambutol (e)
  • • The intensive phase (4 drugs) four drugs regimen for 2 months with daily oral: Rifampicin (r) Isoniazid (h) Pyrazinamide (z) Ethambutol (e)
  • • Rifampicin (r) Isoniazid (h) Pyrazinamide (z) Ethambutol (e)
  • • Rifampicin (r)
  • • Isoniazid (h)
  • • Pyrazinamide (z)
  • • Ethambutol (e)
  • • The continuation phase, three-drug regimen (orally daily for next 4 months) is given using Rifampicin (r) Isoniazid (h) Ethambutol (e)
  • • The continuation phase, three-drug regimen (orally daily for next 4 months) is given using Rifampicin (r) Isoniazid (h) Ethambutol (e)
  • • Rifampicin (r) Isoniazid (h) Ethambutol (e)

questions.text: Which of the following is a common presenting symptom of genital tuberculosis in women?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Irregular menstrual cycles

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The 2 most common symptoms of genital TB include
  • • Menstrual disturbances (initial menorrhagia followed by scanty flow and then secondary amenorrhoea) Infertility (due to salpingitis/ endometritis)
  • • Menstrual disturbances (initial menorrhagia followed by scanty flow and then secondary amenorrhoea)
  • • Infertility (due to salpingitis/ endometritis)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Menstrual disturbances (initial menorrhagia followed by scanty flow and then secondary amenorrhoea) Infertility (due to salpingitis/ endometritis)
  • ➤ Menstrual disturbances (initial menorrhagia followed by scanty flow and then secondary amenorrhoea)
  • ➤ Infertility (due to salpingitis/ endometritis)
